but I had to write it in a hurry.
HLB
Penciled note - Please
flat power glide with his co-pilot hanging out of the window watching the
river and Moon peering ahead for sampans or junks.
When they seemed to
about eight or ten feet off the water the co-pilot yelled and Moon
pulled back on his throttles and eased back on his stick and shut his eyes
and prayed to Buddha.
The next morning he took off for Ichang where he
Landed and filled up his plane with passengers we had left there and
to Chungking.
returned
That completed our job of helping
to evacuate Fankow.
I an glad
It is over.
The men all did a fine job and I am sincerely proud of them,
but
no one could keep that up long.
I don't see how they accomplisbed as much as
they did,
I think the Minister was pleased.
I would like to say that Allison also flew to Hankow every night
for three nights.
The first night there was nothing for háº§m to do so he
returned to Chungking at day break bringing sone of CNACts atafl, a lot of
meil and pay
passengers for CHAC.
The second night, he brought sone aviation
and other officials and mail for ONAC.
The third night after his return
from Fengyang with Sharp, he brought fourteen pay
passengers to Chungking for
CNAG after spending one night en route at Ichang.
He then told me be was
ordered to fly to Kunming on the 29th and would be glad to take passengers
but unfortunately his orders wore changed and he did not go to Kunming,
I don't know if you are still reading this or if you have
consigned it to the waste basket where it rightly belongs.
I think we my say
that one period of the war is ending, and the future may be different.
It
certainly looks bad for China now but actually it seems to me it 1a not really
as bad as it was after the fall of Nanking nearly a year ago.
It is true the
Chinese are worse off but so are the Japanese, much worse off.
They are
getting further from their base, apparently they are realling beginning to feel
the pinch, and they have no more big importent towns or objectives they can
work towards with the feeling that if they can take that,
their situstion will
Also the Japanese are undoubtedly beginning to weaken thenselves at
home and they are getting themselves into a very vulnerable position for some
If the Chinese will just hold on I believe
they have a good chance to get very favourable peace terms.
I think the
Generalissino will certainly keep up the fight.
It all depends on how China
I have been saying for a long time that we should know
Again I think we should.
It may not be
It may be a bad peace for China or it may be the cortain knowledge
that China will keep on fighting to the bitter end but whatever the future has
in store
should be developed in sixty days I think.
It is not a very
pleasant outlook but at lesst CNAG is still
fairly well organized and is/going concern with a little reserve.
I think
GNAC will probably go back into the Red gain before long but by doing a lot
of drastie reorganizing when it becomes necessary we will manage to hold on.
CHAO takes a lot of licking.
Yours vory truly,
Copy Mr. Bixby
WAB LOPJ
(sga.) M. Lo BOND
Penciled note - Our Ford Station wagon and mechanica got to Ichang safely.
SEdONISI POS
